gpt-message.content: You are an expert in hardware design with a deep understanding of Verilog RTL codes. Now I want to train a large language model for code comment generation tasks specifically focused on Verilog RTL codes. And I want you to help me process the raw data, transforming it into suitable formats that can serve as inputs and outputs for the model.

Name of the module and its functionality is as follows: 
Module name: altera_up_avalon_reset_from_locked_signal. Explanation: The module generates a reset signal based on the negation of the input "locked". If "locked" is high (1), the reset output will be low (0), and if "locked" is low (0), the reset output will be high (1), effectively creating an active-low reset signal based on the status of "locked".

Input and output ports and their explanation is as follows: 
Input ports: [locked]. Explanation: The "locked" port is an input signal to the module. This input is used to determine the state of the output reset signal. A high value (1) on "locked" indicates that a system, such as a phase-locked loop (PLL), is in a stable or "locked" state, while a low value (0) suggests it is "unlocked" or not stable.

Output ports: [reset]. Explanation: The "reset" port is the output signal from the module. It is an active-low reset signal, which means it is high (1) when the "locked" input is low (0), and low (0) when the "locked" input is high (1). This output is used to control the reset functionality in other parts of a system, typically to initialize or reset them when the "locked" condition is not met.

Internal signals and their explanation is as follows: 
Internal signals: [None]. Explanation: The module does not use any internal signals. There is only a direct assignment operation from the input "locked" to the output "reset" using a logic negation (~). This direct connection implies that the function is simple and does not require additional internal signals to implement its behavior.
